awd_titl_txt: Guest-Induced Electrical Conductivity and Photovoltaic Activity of Metal-Organic Frameworks
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
The prospect of advancing modern technologies in a clean, safe, and sustainable way depends on constant innovation and supply of new functional materials that can produce and store energy and perform myriad other complex functions. Self-assembled from metal ion clusters and organic linkers, crystalline porous materials known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) exhibit remarkable synthetic simplicity, structural diversity, and size-selective guest uptake capacity, which make them attractive platforms for a variety of advanced applications. Although their practical applications are well documented, electronic and photonic MOFs are still at their infancy and evolving rapidly. Supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program of the National Science Foundation, this project focuses on developing stimuli-responsive MOFs that not only capture complementary guest molecules inside their cavities, but also engage them in specific electronic interactions to stimulate new properties and functions, particularly, charge conduction and light to electrical energy conversion. Precisely oriented films of electro- and photoactive MOFs grown on functionalized electrodes are integrated into prototype devices to exploit the preorganized porous architectures filled with complementary guests to promote directional charge movement in electrical and photovolatic devices. Systematic structure-property relationship studies demonstrate how stimuli-responsive MOFs adapt to different physical and chemical inputs and how their tunable electronic and optical properties can be exploited. In addition to providing graduate students and postdoctoral researchers a cutting-edge research and learning environment, this interdisciplinary project is enabling the PI to engage undergraduate and high school students in research, motivate younger generation to pursue higher education in science and technology through outreach activities at local schools and science museum, and raise the public awareness on the importance of basic research by discussing scientific breakthroughs in public forums. 

Technical Abstract:
The electrical conductivity and photovoltaic activity are among the most coveted but remote properties of metal-organic frameworks. The lack of intrinsic charge carrier density and the light-harvesting capability, however, deprives many existing porous frameworks of tunable electronic and optical properties that are key to their abilities to serve as viable semiconductors and photovoltaic materials. To address these issues and transform MOFs into viable electronic and photonic materials, in this project, the PI and his team are (1) constructing stimuli-responsive MOFs based on redox- and photoactive ligands that can interact with and respond to various guests, applied electric field, and light to create new non-native properties, (2) growing robust, oriented MOF-films in a bottom-up fashion on functionalized electrode surfaces that can promote directional charge movement, and (3) doping these stimuli-responsive MOF films with complementary redox-active guests that can produce mobile charge carriers by interacting with the ligands and facilitate charge dispersion through the frameworks by forming extended ð-stacks. The current-voltage profiles of MOF films measured before and after guest infiltration and in the presence and absence of light reveal their stimuli-responsive nature and the impact of the encapsulated electroactive guests on their electronic and optical properties. Since guest intercalation is a ubiquitous and non-destructive process, it can be adopted broadly to engineer non-native electrical and photonic behaviors in any adaptive MOFs. The prototype MOF-based solar cells developed in the PI's lab are also used for outreach activities to demonstrate light to electrical energy conversion to K-12 students and motivate them to pursue higher education in science, technology, engineering, and math.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit: Fostering technological advances while also limiting anthropogenic strains on our environment are among the biggest challenges of the 21st century. Addressing these dueling issues necessitates continuous innovation and supply of smart functional materials that can generate, transport, and store clean energy, as well as detect and remedy harmful agents and greenhouse gases. Owing to their straightforward access through solvothermal reactions, tunable structures and properties that can be customized by varying the molecular building blocks, high tolerance to various postsynthetic modifications and guest encapsulation that create new properties, crystalline porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) made of metal ions and organic ligands show unparalleled potentials to address myriad technological challenges ranging from CO2 capture and chemical sensing to solar energy conversion and charge transport and storage. To address these challenges, with the support of NSF grant #1809092, the Saha research group at Clemson University have developed a number of electronic and photonic MOFs that can convert light to electrical energy, transport electronic and ionic charges, and enable visual sensing of toxic mercury(II) ion through luminescence changes. Furthermore, our fundamental studies have delivered new design and synthetic strategies and revealed structure-property relationships and operating principles of these materials. 

As electrical conductivity is a product of charge carrier density and charge mobility, to develop electrically conducting MOFs, we have employed redox-active organic ligands, metal ions, and guest entities, which not only serve as charge carrier sources but also help create long-range through-bond, through-space, and/or guest-mediated conduction pathways. For example, we have developed a three-dimensional Ag–HATHCN MOF based on a highly electron deficient hexaazatriphenylene-heaxacarbonitrile (HATHCN) ligand, which gains electron density from Ag(I)-bound triflate counterions via anion–pi interaction and enables through-bond charge transport vis staircase-like Ag–HATHCN coordination network to generate impressive intrinsic electrical conductivity (7.3 ´ 10–4 S/cm) of the framework (ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2020). Using an electron-rich tetrathiafulvalene tetracarboxylate (TTFTC) ligand, we have constructed a family of M–TTFTC MOFs (M = Na, K, Rb, and Cs) having variable electrical conductivity and band gap, which are dictated by the efficacy of through-space charge delocalization via intervalence charge transfer (IVCT) interaction between mixed-valent TTFTC0/•+ ligands (Chem. Sci. 2021). As the pi–pi-stacking distances between overlapping TTFTC ligands increased while the population of aerobically oxidized TTFTC•+ radical cations decreased systematically, the conductivity of these MOFs diminished commensurately—Na-MOF > K-MOF > Rb-MOF >> Cs-MOF—due to fading through-space charge transport via IVCT interactions. 

Two-dimensional graphitic MOFs (GMOFs) composed of square-planar transition metal ions and trigonal planar hexa-amino-, oxo-, and thio- tripheneylene ligands (HXTP) usually benefit from efficient through-bond charge transport within hexagonal coordination planes. However, much weaker out-of-plane charge transport across offset-parallel layers renders the conductivity highly direction-dependent and dampens bulk conductivity. To reduce the disparity between orthogonal in-plane and out-of-plane conduction pathways and boost their bulk conductivity, we have developed a novel design strategy and an elegant bottom-up synthetic method to construct the first π-intercalated 2D GMOF (iGMOF-1) featuring hexagonal Cu–HXTP layers, which enabled through-bond in-plane charge transport, and built-in alternating π-donor/acceptor stacks of π-donor HXTP ligands and intercalated π-acceptor molecules, which simultaneously promoted through-space out-of-plane charge transport (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2023). As a result, iGMOF-1 attained remarkably high electrical conductivity (0.25 S/cm) and narrow band gap (<0.1 eV), demonstrating the benefits of simultaneous in-plane and out-of-plane charge transport in orthogonal directions. 

In addition to these intrinsically conducting MOFs having built-in charge transport pathways, we have also enhanced the conductivity of poor conducting MOFs by introducing iodine, which oxidized electron-rich TTF ligands of MOFs and facilitated through-space charge transport (ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2020; Mater. Adv. 2022) and conducting polymers and gold nanoparticles inside insulating MOF pores via postsynthetic guest modifications, which not only facilitated charge transport but also reinforced framework structures, preventing them from collapsing upon solvent evacuation (Materials Today Chem. 2022; ACS Appl. Nanomater. 2022; Inorg. Chem. 2023).

We have also developed a Li+-ion conducting MOF, which can potentially function as solid electrolyte in rechargeable batteries (ACS Sus. Chem. Eng. 2019); a Zn-porphyrin-based light-harvesting MOF, which converted light to electricity in prototype solar cells (ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2018), and a luminescent MOF capable of naked-eye mercury sensing (Inorg. Chem. 2019). 

Broader Impact: This NSF-funded research project has produced 15 peer-reviewed publications and 23 research presentations at national, international, and regional conferences. It has also enabled me to produce 4 PhD graduates (including 2 Latinas) who are now employed at Dow Chemicals, Intel, and CATL Battery Co., mentor graduate (3), undergraduate (3), and postdoctoral (1) researchers, and high-school students (2), and perform outreach activities at local schools, which benefitted the society at large.
